medium: Ink and light colors on silk
title: Autumn Landscape
text: Okada Hanko_ was the son of the rice merchant and wildly eccentric painter Beisanjin. Hanko_'s own painting style, however, reflects the much more conservative approach prevalent among <I>nanga<I> artists active in Kyoto at the end of the nineteenth century. Greater exposure to actual Chinese paintings imported from the mainland helped these Japanese artists perfect the subtleties of their brush techniques and compositional arrangements. Hanko_'s inscription on this painting, in fact, reveals that it is a copy of a work by Tung Hsiao-ch'u, a little known artist of China's Ming dynasty.
description: large, densely painted landscape of bare trees, a scholar\'s retreat in a valley with piled-up layers of pointy mountain peaks
creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
